METS:xmlData.dcterms:title: Transnistrian (Il)licit Flows: How an Unrecognized State Copes with the Global Economy
METS:xmlData.dcterms:alternative: Pridnjestrski (ne)dovoljeni tokovi: kako se nepriznana država spopada z globalno ekonomijo
METS:xmlData.dcterms:creator: Lesanu, Alexandru
METS:xmlData.dcterms:subject: Pridnjestrski
nepriznana država
globalna ekonomija
Transnistrian
unrecognized state
global economy
METS:xmlData.dcterms:publisher: Oddelek za zgodovino Filozofske fakultete Univerze v Ljubljani, Ljubljana

METS:xmlData.entity:description: Konec leta 1991 je mednarodna skupnost priznala zahteve po neodvisnosti petnajstih zveznih republik Sovjetske zveze, vendar so številni znotraj teh meja hrepeneli po lastni neodvisnosti. Vzhodna območja nove Republike Moldavije niso hotela priznati novih moldavskih oblasti in so razglasila svojo de facto državo, Pridnjestrsko moldavsko republiko, ki je znana tudi kot Transnistrija. Pridnjestrska republika danes dejansko deluje kot suverena država, vendar mednarodna skupnost in moldavske oblasti v Kišinjevu še vedno niso uradno priznale njene neodvisnosti. Številno opazovalci opozarjajo, da je zaradi nejasnega mednarodnega statusa postala središče tihotapljenja alkoholnih pijač, orožja in drog. Ker ni mednarodno priznana, to različnim interesnim skupinam nedvomno omogoča, da jo uporabljajo kot verigo za tihotapljenje različnega blaga ali pranje denarja. Vendar je zaradi tega prišlo tudi do stanja, v katerem uradno štejejo za nezakonite vsi gospodarski posli. Ker moldavske oblasti nimajo dejanskega nadzora znotraj meja Pridnjestrske republike, obravnavajo vse blago, ki vstopi na ozemlje te republike, kot nedovoljeno, ne glede na to, ali gre za droge in orožje ali pa za živila in energijo. Posledično vsa pridnjestrska podjetja opravljajo svojo gospodarsko dejavnost v vmesnem prostoru med zakonitostjo notranjih pridnjestrskih zakonov in nezakonitostjo v širšem mednarodnem pravnem okviru. V prispevku predstavljam primer edine pridnjestrske tovarne sladkorja v Rîbniți, s katerim ponazarjam, kako pridnjestrska podjetja manevrirajo med zakonitim statusom znotraj meja de facto države in nezakonitim statusom v mednarodnem prostoru.

At the end of 1991, the international community recognized claims of independence by the fifteen union-level republics of the Soviet Union, yet many within those borders yearned for their own independence. The eastern districts of the new Republic of Moldova refused to recognize the new Moldovan authorities and proclaimed their own de facto state, the Transnistrian Moldavian Republic or Transnistria as it is better known to the English speaking public. Today, Transnistria operates as a de facto sovereign state, yet its independence still remains officially unrecognized by the international community and by Moldovan authorities in Chisinau. Many observers have pointed to Transnistria’s unclear international status to explain its emergence as a hub for smuggling goods like alcohol, weapons, and drugs. Undoubtedly, the lack of international recognition created opportunities for various interest groups to use Transnistria as a chain in the smuggling of goods or money laundering schemes. Yet, this also created a situation where all economic transactions are considered technically illegal. With no de facto control inside the borders of Transnistria, Moldovan authorities treat any goods that enter Transnistrian territory as illicit, whether they be drugs and weapons or food and energy. As a result, all Transnistrian enterprises conduct their economic activities in the interstitial space between the legality of internal Transnistrian laws and the illegality of a broader international legal framework. In this paper, I will use the example of Rybnitsa Sugar Factory, the only Transnistrian sugar factory, to illustrate how a Transnistrian enterprise maneuvers between its licit status inside the boundaries of a de facto state and its illicit status on the international stage.
